push-api apparently allows (and enforces in certain cases) wrapping after an equals sign of an attribute. That's a new one.
hi all! I'm the main guy who runs the State of JS/CSS/etc. surveys. Always happy to get feedback to help make them more helpful for the community :)

keithamus: heya, I could make time today for https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/9841, but I was wondering if you could squash all the commits and rebase on top of main as there are conflicts at the moment
content.formatted_body: keithamus: heya, I could make time today for https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/9841, but I was wondering if you could squash all the commits and rebase on top of main as there are conflicts at the moment

content.formatted_body: keithamus: I also see some minor issues such as wrapping before a closing tag (</code></dfn>) and indentation beyond the start tag on the preceding line that you might want to tackle while doing that?

content.body: WPT PR is also out-of-date it seems
annevk: sure, I‚Äôm just about to get on the road but in about an hour I‚Äôll update both spec and wpt pr
content.formatted_body: annevk: sure, I‚Äôm just about to get on the road but in about an hour I‚Äôll update both spec and wpt pr

content.body: keithamus: oh I see that in August 27 I also expressed confusion as to how this event could work. That comment was never addressed.
content.formatted_body: keithamus: oh I see that in August 27 I also expressed confusion as to how this event could work. That comment was never addressed.

content.body: I'm also once again confused at the compatibility story we ended up with around potentially changing the default of button type. Trying to find the relevant minutes...
Found it: https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/10441
keithamus: so what I think I'm missing is changes to the `button` element `type` attribute reflection that take that into account
content.formatted_body: keithamus: so what I think I'm missing is changes to the button element type attribute reflection that take that into account

content.body: keithamus: in that we want the `type` getter to return `button` when the `button` element has `command` and `commandfor` attributes
content.formatted_body: keithamus: in that we want the type getter to return button when the button element has command and commandfor attributes

content.body: It's a bit subtle as the `type` getter can mismatch with the actual state, but that seems okay-ish.
content.formatted_body: It's a bit subtle as the type getter can mismatch with the actual state, but that seems okay-ish.

content.body: Okay, apologies I thought we resolved the other way around. So we want the button to _not_ be a submit button if it has `command` or `commandfor`? It should be in the `button` state.
content.formatted_body: Okay, apologies I thought we resolved the other way around. So we want the button to not be a submit button if it has command or commandfor? It should be in the button state.

content.body: keithamus: I suspect the easiest way to do this is to introduce a Maybe Button state. The type getter would return "button" in that state. When associated with a form the button wouldn't work and when outside a form it would act like a button.
content.formatted_body: keithamus: I suspect the easiest way to do this is to introduce a Maybe Button state. The type getter would return "button" in that state. When associated with a form the button wouldn't work and when outside a form it would act like a button.

content.body: So I think behavior-wise it's pretty much what you have, except that it doesn't account for the `type` getter.
content.formatted_body: So I think behavior-wise it's pretty much what you have, except that it doesn't account for the type getter.

content.body: so i could have a type submit that isn't a submit button? O.o that seems bad
* so i could have an explicit type submit that isn't a submit button? O.o that seems bad

m.new_content.body: so i could have an explicit type submit that isn't a submit button? O.o that seems bad

content.body: And then I think there's the separate question of what should happen when type is set to submit or reset and you have these command/commandfor attributes. Perhaps in that case the command/commandfor attributes are to be ignored? Luke Warlow was looking at this for popover at some point.
content.formatted_body: And then I think there's the separate question of what should happen when type is set to submit or reset and you have these command/commandfor attributes. Perhaps in that case the command/commandfor attributes are to be ignored? Luke Warlow was looking at this for popover at some point.

content.body: * so i could have an explicit type submit that isn't a submit button? O.o that seems bad (when no `type` is provided, anything that lets it default to `button` is an improvement, defaulting to `submit` is painful)
content.formatted_body: * so i could have an explicit type submit that isn't a submit button? O.o that seems bad (when no type is provided, anything that lets it default to button is an improvement, defaulting to submit is painful)

m.new_content.formatted_body: so i could have an explicit type submit that isn't a submit button? O.o that seems bad (when no type is provided, anything that lets it default to button is an improvement, defaulting to submit is painful)

content.body: ljharb: the problem is that `<button>` defaults to being a submit button, which is not necessarily great for new use cases.
content.formatted_body: ljharb: the problem is that <button> defaults to being a submit button, which is not necessarily great for new use cases.

content.body: right - it's a very bad default, and when `type` is omitted, i think it's totally fine to quietly make it `button` when it has a new attribute
content.formatted_body: right - it's a very bad default, and when type is omitted, i think it's totally fine to quietly make it button when it has a new attribute

content.body: but if i explicitly put `type="submit"` then violating that seems bad to me
content.formatted_body: but if i explicitly put type="submit" then violating that seems bad to me

content.body: Yeah agreed.
(i just learned about command/commandFor recently, btw, and it seems very cool - is there a polyfill anywhere for its behavior?)

(The main reason why we're not defaulting to button inside a form immediately is because of backwards compatibility with browsers where it would submit the form. But five years from now or so we can change that as well.)

> <@ljharb:matrix.org> (i just learned about command/commandFor recently, btw, and it seems very cool - is there a polyfill anywhere for its behavior?)

https://github.com/keithamus/invokers-polyfill is what I have so far
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @ljharb:matrix.org
(i just learned about command/commandFor recently, btw, and it seems very cool - is there a polyfill anywhere for its behavior?)
https://github.com/keithamus/invokers-polyfill is what I have so far

content.body:
> <@annevk:matrix.org> And then I think there's the separate question of what should happen when type is set to submit or reset and you have these command/commandfor attributes. Perhaps in that case the command/commandfor attributes are to be ignored? Luke Warlow was looking at this for popover at some point.

So I think if the button is explicit submit and has commandfor/command we should make it submit, ignore the command stuff, and browsers can log a warning to the console telling the user they've made a mistake
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @annevk:matrix.org
And then I think there's the separate question of what should happen when type is set to submit or reset and you have these command/commandfor attributes. Perhaps in that case the command/commandfor attributes are to be ignored? Luke Warlow was looking at this for popover at some point.
So I think if the button is explicit submit and has commandfor/command we should make it submit, ignore the command stuff, and browsers can log a warning to the console telling the user they've made a mistake

content.body: The other choice is to not do either behaviour (submit nor command/commandfor)
Agreed, I just wrote that down in https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/9625#issuecomment-2464496320
annevk: how would I type the command attribute state? (Trying to address https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/9841/files#r1834138912). It's not a string, I presume (it's an enum in the impls).
content.formatted_body: annevk: how would I type the command attribute state? (Trying to address https://github.com/whatwg/html/pull/9841/files#r1834138912). It's not a string, I presume (it's an enum in the impls).

content.body: keithamus: in HTML it's a string, unless you introduced a concept that only contains the relevant string values, in which case you could use that concept, but I don't think that exists
content.formatted_body: keithamus: in HTML it's a string, unless you introduced a concept that only contains the relevant string values, in which case you could use that concept, but I don't think that exists

content.body: okay great I'll use a string
Oh wait, the state hmm
I was thinking the actual value

content.formatted_body: keithamus: hmm maybe it's easier to just pass in the element that has the attribute or some such

content.body: oh yeah okay
hmm... but an event is dispatched before the steps are called so referencing the element might be bad, it could change during the event phase...
keithamus: maybe just do state _state_ for now then. And don't talk about it being in a state, but being a state. "If command is the Close or Show Modal state, then return true."
content.formatted_body: keithamus: maybe just do state state for now then. And don't talk about it being in a state, but being a state. "If command is the Close or Show Modal state, then return true."

content.body: Why would reordering them change anything spec-wise?

This seems like an implementation concern. I couldn't find anything in the spec that would be problematic because of this, and we've added pretty good test coverage for this type of scenario (though there could always be more)
Dominic Farolino did the iframe work though so perhaps I'm missing something.
content.formatted_body: Dominic Farolino did the iframe work though so perhaps I'm missing something.

content.body:
> <@smaug:mozilla.org> (Implementations haven't removed mutation events)

It should be trivial to not fire them during moveBefore though, and they‚Äôre not in the spec
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @smaug:mozilla.org
(Implementations haven't removed mutation events)
It should be trivial to not fire them during moveBefore though, and they‚Äôre not in the spec

content.body: (Oh and it seems that Shannon Booth from Ladybird also has some good ShadowRealm feedback.)
Thanks again, I think :)

There's nothing in the spec that's problematic regarding to this simply because the spec doesn't handle (at all) what we've referred to colloquially as the session history re-parenting issue ‚Äî i.e., the case where upon going back to a non-bfcached page, the browser tries to reconcile the structure of the DOM with the structure of the nested session history, and load the latest nested session history items into the corresponding iframes.

So first, that's bad in general. But I don't think it intersects too much with moveBefore(). moveBefore() doesn't change the order of the iframes from the perspective of the browser process, session history, or other iframes that can reach these iframes via proxies. That is, it doesn't re-order window.frames: https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/web_tests/external/wpt/dom/nodes/moveBefore/tentative/iframe-document-preserve.window.js;l=110-116;drc=0ba2bf02d3c2d6bf52c53012cdb5993b50ba82ed

* So first, that's bad in general. But I don't think it intersects too much with moveBefore(). moveBefore() doesn't change the order of the iframes from the perspective of the browser process, session history, or other iframes that can reach the moved iframes via proxies. That is, it doesn't re-order window.frames: https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third\_party/blink/web\_tests/external/wpt/dom/nodes/moveBefore/tentative/iframe-document-preserve.window.js;l=110-116;drc=0ba2bf02d3c2d6bf52c53012cdb5993b50ba82ed
content.formatted_body: * So first, that's bad in general. But I don't think it intersects too much with moveBefore(). moveBefore() doesn't change the order of the iframes from the perspective of the browser process, session history, or other iframes that can reach the moved iframes via proxies. That is, it doesn't re-order window.frames: https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/web_tests/external/wpt/dom/nodes/moveBefore/tentative/iframe-document-preserve.window.js;l=110-116;drc=0ba2bf02d3c2d6bf52c53012cdb5993b50ba82ed

That is, it doesn't re-order window.frames: https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third\_party/blink/web\_tests/external/wpt/dom/nodes/moveBefore/tentative/iframe-document-preserve.window.js;l=110-116;drc=0ba2bf02d3c2d6bf52c53012cdb5993b50ba82ed

That is, it doesn't re-order window.frames: https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:third_party/blink/web_tests/external/wpt/dom/nodes/moveBefore/tentative/iframe-document-preserve.window.js;l=110-116;drc=0ba2bf02d3c2d6bf52c53012cdb5993b50ba82ed

content.body: So I think navigating backwards to the non-bfcached top-level page should behave the same as it would be if said page did not use moveBefore() before it was navigated away.

> <@smaug:mozilla.org> (Implementations haven't removed mutation events, https://github.com/whatwg/dom/issues/305#issuecomment-2306411923)

smaug: Implementations must disable mutation events when this API runs: https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/dom/nodes/moveBefore/tentative/mutation-events.html. We can't spec it because mutation events don't exist in DOM, but we've tested it. either way, yeah I don't think this blocks stage 3 or shipping.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @smaug:mozilla.org
(Implementations haven't removed mutation events, https://github.com/whatwg/dom/issues/305#issuecomment-2306411923)
smaug: Implementations must disable mutation events when this API runs: https://github.com/web-platform-tests/wpt/blob/master/dom/nodes/moveBefore/tentative/mutation-events.html. We can't spec it because mutation events don't exist in DOM, but we've tested it. either way, yeah I don't think this blocks stage 3 or shipping.

content.body: Domenic: I've looked but I can't find a bug tracking the iframe session history reparent/restoration problem. Do you know if one exists? This is the case where you navigate backwards to a top-level non-bfcached page with iframes, and try and reconcile the page's iframe structure with the nested iframe history structure, to load the latest iframe history entries in the page's iframes..
content.formatted_body: Domenic: I've looked but I can't find a bug tracking the iframe session history reparent/restoration problem. Do you know if one exists? This is the case where you navigate backwards to a top-level non-bfcached page with iframes, and try and reconcile the page's iframe structure with the nested iframe history structure, to load the latest iframe history entries in the page's iframes..

content.body: Well, there hasn't been any need for "reparenting" before
We've tested that `moveBefore` doesn't reorder `window.frames`, and some of the places in the spec collect `navigables` in tree order
content.formatted_body: We've tested that moveBefore doesn't reorder window.frames, and some of the places in the spec collect navigables in tree order

content.body: This is a new thing caused by moveBefore
Ok, and if you go back to a page which had iframes reordered, what gets restored to iframes?
No change from before I guess?

For this kind of bug to occur you need to save the tree order of navigables somehow separate from the tree order of frames and have them out of sync due to `moveBefore`. I can see how a bug like that might occur in implementation but not in the spec
content.formatted_body: For this kind of bug to occur you need to save the tree order of navigables somehow separate from the tree order of frames and have them out of sync due to moveBefore. I can see how a bug like that might occur in implementation but not in the spec

oh, Element had hidden those messages well from me

haha no worries. Yeah I understand the concern here, but I think from the perspective of things outside of the local DOM inside of the Document that experienced the moveBefore, nothing changes regarding child frame order, including in session history.

PSA: If your environment is macOS and you‚Äôre working on an HTML spec PR and when you try to run the `./build.sh` script and the build fails with an *‚Äúld: library 'System' not found‚Äù* error (in the Rust part of the build), the run the build script like this:
```
PATH=/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/SDKs/MacOSX.sdk/usr/lib:$PATH \
LIBRARY_PATH="$LIBRARY_PATH:/Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/SDKs/MacOSX.sdk/usr/lib \
./build.sh
```
‚Ä¶or else just export those `PATH` and `LIBRARY_PATH` settings to your environment (e.g., in your `~/.bashrc` or wherever).
